reviews.text: The film creates an alluring combination of the familiar and the fresh.
reviews.author: Christina Newland

reviews.text: "The Batman" has a somber tone different from previous versions that, due to its enunciation, bring it closer to the style of the Film-Noir film genre, returning to the original style of the comic strip and its proximity to pulp literature.
reviews.author: Denise Pieniazek

reviews.text: When it’s all said and done, The Batman is good—not great. From technical and narrative standpoints, there are both gaps and achievements.
reviews.author: Brittany Patrice Witherspoon

reviews.text: For a film set deep in the depths of Gotham’s gritty underbelly, the script slowly descends into the chaotic silliness of the characters that it feels so desperate to shed
reviews.author: Connor Lightbody

reviews.text: The Batman is a gritty psychological crime thriller featuring the most Gotham-esqe Gotham we’ve seen yet.
reviews.author: Nadya Martinez

reviews.text: It’s certainly a better film than any of the Zack Snyder ones. But that’s not exactly a high bar to set.
reviews.author: Joonatan Itkonen

reviews.text: This film is beautifully gritty and simply a great detective story. It takes Batman to his roots and acknowledges the silliness of a sad, orphan boy in a rubber suit.
reviews.author: Zach Youngs

reviews.text: It starts with an original vision of the hero, has an inspired cast, creates a self-sufficient story and elevates it with a stylized direction that's in line with the film's substance. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Benjamín Harguindey

reviews.text: The Batman is an ALL TIME BEST FILM. Matt Reeves has crafted the DEFINITIVE take on The Caped Crusader that Pattinson will define for generations to come. Brooding and brutal, I didn’t want it to end.
reviews.author: Daniel Baptista

reviews.text: The Batman isn’t just another entry in a trilogy or a multi-directed Batman starring three Bruce Wayne’s. It’s a love letter to fans who have waited decades for a faithful adaptation of Batman.
reviews.author: Christian Eulinberg

reviews.text: This latest Batman tale is grounded, noir and detective based, and a highly realistic entry into the movie mythos of the caped crusader.
reviews.author: Jeffrey Peterson

reviews.text: It’s a part-serial killer mystery, part-superhero adventure, and part-crime drama stuffed in a 3-hour runtime that can feel loaded but never dull.
reviews.author: Ryan Oquiza

reviews.text: Not only does the central plot feel like a rehashing of other films and comic books, the entire movie plays like a patchwork quilt of past works.
reviews.author: Rick Bentley

reviews.text: A phenomenal take on the caped crusader that will leave you wanting more from this Batman world.
reviews.author: Cris Parker

reviews.text: The Batman becomes less of a full-throttle action romp and more of a detective tale, an arc that hasn’t been filmed before.
reviews.author: Hector A. Gonzalez

reviews.text: BEST Batman Film yet…. Beautifully made with incredible action sequences, a thrilling mystery, & amazing characters. You can’t get any better than this & wherever smart Reeves goes next door will I.
reviews.author: Zach Pope

reviews.text: With an incredible score by Michael Giacchino, and a backdrop of Nirvana songs to elevate the mood, The Batman is a fantastic film. The acting and fighting sequences will keep audiences on the edge of their seats.
reviews.author: Matthew Creith

reviews.text: Matt Reeves delivers a distinctly darker, more intense, frighteningly realistic noir thriller than past adaptations, with an aggressively vengeful Bruce Wayne / Batman and a fear-inducing, mysterious, lunatic Riddler.
reviews.author: Manuel São Bento

reviews.text: Even with a runtime of nearly three hours, The Batman leaves the audience wanting more. While ultimately fumbling the ending, the characters, performances, plot, and visual appearance leave enough behind to warrant a return to this version of Gotham.
reviews.author: Tina Kakadelis

reviews.text: The Batman is everything a superhero film should be. It’s gritty, stylistic, and most importantly, there’s an intrinsic balance between the action and quiet moments, which Matt Reeves masters superbly through this adaptation.
reviews.author: Gissane Sophia

reviews.text: In a lot of ways, the disjointed editing in The Batman leaves much for the viewer to process; not enough time exists for key character moments.
reviews.author: Peter Bell

reviews.text: ... In this Batman -- very different from Nolan's, Burton's or Schumacher's -- everything seems more appeased, more contained, more... human. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Diego Batlle

reviews.text: They turned revealing an antagonist's presence to the audience without the victim's knowledge into a suspense-driven art. Here, Reeves taps directly into these tactics to phenomenal effect...
reviews.author: William Jones

reviews.text: This is the ultimate Batman movie.
reviews.author: Steph Cozza

reviews.text: Batman's superpower has always been that he's the smartest guy in the room. ... His title as the Dark Knight Detective has never been showcased on film as well as it was in The Batman.
reviews.author: Jonathan Garcia

reviews.text: It may take three hours for Bruce to learn this lesson, but it's an incredible three hours. It may be fun to watch Pattinson put on black make-up and strap into the Batsuit to fight some bad guys, but there's much more to this story than just that.
reviews.author: Alex Billington

reviews.text: THE BATMAN exceeds my expectations and passes the bar of a reboot. It justifies its own existence with great storytelling, insights into humanity and human society, and powerful performances.
reviews.author: Dolores Quintana

reviews.text: “The Batman” reaches for an ingenious and compelling new way to tell a story about the thin lines between corruption, greed and nobility — but ever so limply and always just out of its grasp.
reviews.author: Candice Frederick

reviews.text: Matt Reeves’ The Batman brings us closest to the essence of the Batman character than any film adapted from the DC comics have since Tim Burton’s inaugural Batman in 1989.
reviews.author: Wesley Lovell

reviews.text: The Batman is a brave, bold and brilliant new take on a familiar character and Reeves and Pattinson have done him proud.
reviews.author: Dallas King

reviews.text: Matt Reeves’ The Batman is a brutal, uncompromising vision that leaves its indelible mark in comic book film history.
reviews.author: M.N. Miller

reviews.text: The film casts long shadows with blacks and grays, but the consistent, bleeding flashes of red paint the most intense moments with jarring contrast.
reviews.author: Maggie Lovitt

reviews.text: The Batman is the only comic book adaptation since The Dark Knight to come close to recreating that cinematic achievement, brilliantly blending entertainment with artistry.
reviews.author: Zoë Rose Bryant

reviews.text: Reeves, it should be noted, assembles a lot of other people’s ideas and themes into this mammoth package. The movie is a triumph of craft and design, but original it ain’t.
reviews.author: Rob Gonsalves

reviews.text: Reeves’ vision is fresh and innovative, building a young (but not brand new) version of the Bat world that is satisfying as a single film, while planting the seeds for a juggernaut franchise.
reviews.author: Ron Seoul-Oh

reviews.text: The Batman transcends an oversaturated genre and gives arguably the best portrayal of the caped crusader yet. Matt Reeves delivers a slow-burn detective noir with a terrifying villain and ever-rising tension. A rare film that I would call a masterpiece!
reviews.author: Cody Leach

reviews.text: Writer-director Matt Reeves knows how to write a blockbuster with brains, and he knows how to film one with visual flare.
reviews.author: Scott Phillips

reviews.text: The way that everything is spliced and shaken together, and the mood — and it's definitely a mood — makes this weighty, heavy, sublimely shot, excellently cast, always-engaging blockbuster feel new, and all things Batman with it.
reviews.author: Sarah Ward

reviews.text: THE BATMAN shows that even the best intentions may inspire mayhem, cause heck this is Gotham.
reviews.author: Rosalie Kicks

reviews.author: Erick Estrada

reviews.text: How many times can this story be told? Next time pray that the filmmakers aren’t this self-serious about their own vision and that the running time values your time outside of Gotham.
reviews.author: Nathaniel Rogers

reviews.text: Lovers of action, fight sequences, digital effects, and mainstream fare may be driven to mental torture. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Javier Ocaña

reviews.text: Matt Reeves is a director with a vision. I'm glad I enjoy that vision, because Batman needs to have good movies.
reviews.author: Kent Garrison

reviews.text: It is a victory of story and a failure of plot.
reviews.author: Grant Watson

reviews.text: If they had to do one more go on dark, broody, loner, brutal Batman and they decided the selling point was going to be a push into noir... if it had to happen, this is not a bad result. Actually it's pretty good.
reviews.author: Vera Wylde

reviews.text: Do we actually need another brooding Bat-flick of this type? Not really -- a little of Vincent Price prancing around as Egghead would be a welcome sight right about now -- but given its assignment, it mostly gets the job done.
reviews.author: Matt Brunson

reviews.text: Operatic, simmering, and replete with a smoky noir atmosphere, The Batman is an enthralling package of contradictions.
reviews.author: Eric Francisco

reviews.text: more procedural than action movie, a kind of DC Universe version of Seven (1995)
reviews.author: James Kendrick

reviews.author: Jeff Beck

reviews.text: More than a superhero film –there is little "super" about the masked hero– it is a contemporary film noir with touches of absolute terror. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.text:
Solid and fleshed out.
[Full review in Spanish]

reviews.text:
A solid and adult thriller…with constant rhythm that draws away from the traditional blockbuster.
[Full review in Spanish]

A dazzling, enveloped, night-time spectacle.

A no man's land that will not comfort the multiplex spectators in search of adrenaline...

reviews.text: A Batman that has never been seen in cinema. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.author: Carey-Ann Pawsey

reviews.text: "The Batman" is an installment of an often-depicted superhero that manages to give a fresh take. Both atmosphere and plot are dark and heavy. This may not be the kind of movie for those who lean more towards the MarvelDisney fanfare.
reviews.author: Chauncey K. Robinson

reviews.text: Overlong but quite strong as an origin story that works on an emotional level by the end. The cast handles this material well, making it more of a detective yarn with hints of commentary about privilege by the end that could've been fleshed out more.
reviews.author: Jim Laczkowski

reviews.text: A fairly good mock up for a Batman film templated as a graphic novel. Its dark and seedy mood is new backdrop for the Batman films but in terms of showcasing what this cape crusader has to offer in story telling, there is nothing new here.
reviews.author: Alachia Queen

reviews.text: If it's neither fun nor searing, even those iconic pointy ears might struggle to hear the point.
reviews.author: Matt Pais

reviews.text: The Batman shows that Reeves interpretation is one that knows that Caped Crusader was always as famous for his brains as his brawn
reviews.author: Laurence Boyce

reviews.text: It appears that Warner Brothers holy union with HBO MAX has rubbed off on them. diandrareviews
reviews.author: Diandra Reviews

reviews.text: Thanks to Pattinson and Danos compelling performances, as well as Reevess ambitious direction, The Batman is an enthralling thriller and a welcome return for the Caped Crusader.
reviews.author: Katie Smith-Wong

reviews.text: Matt Reeves The Batman is a riveting and passionately crafted film noir that wears its inspiration on its sleeve while bringing Detective Batman to the big screen.
reviews.author: Rendy Jones

reviews.text: hose seeking a grim reflection of our times, will find it; those seeking an escape likely will not. And yet, depressive as it is, the film is electrifying, potent, fun.

reviews.text: Pattinson successfully goes back in time with this character...
reviews.author: Sucharita Tyagi

reviews.text: I didn’t think I wanted another Batman movie. But it turns out that Matt Reeves’s The Batman -- starring Robert Pattinson, who played Edward Cullen in the Twilight films -- has the Batman we need.
reviews.author: Kathryn Reklis

reviews.text: Matt Reeves and Robert Pattinson made it look easy to make a new great Batman movie. Greig Fraser, Colin Pharrell and Paul Dano steal the show. The best Gotham out there in a universe full of potential. Full review in Spanish
reviews.author: Victor Pineyro

reviews.text: Reeves takes inspiration from numerous comic storylines, mixing and matching to concoct an elaborate tapestry that overflows with iconic characters in differing stages of repute. While not as emotive as his Apes films, the blockbuster spectacle remain.
reviews.author: Jared Mobarak

reviews.text: Always great to see a director with a distinct vision amidst a pool of adaptations. Matt Reeves commits to it and offers a rumination closer to Munich than whacks and pows.
reviews.author: Erik Childress

reviews.text: It doesnt execute every second of its runtime perfectly, but its sense of ambition and drive buoy its entire epic narrative, giving us a reason to get excited about Batman at the movies once again.
reviews.author: Matthew Jackson

reviews.text: Strange, squalid and sinister, Matt Reeves' version is dark and deadly.
reviews.author: Susan Granger

reviews.text: "The Batman" offers several great action pieces, but the movie does begin to crumble under its own weight, both in terms of the near-three-hour runtime and its own self-importance.
reviews.author: Matthew Passantino

reviews.text: Perhaps the biggest indictment of Gotham City is that even the villains feel a burning need to fight crime and corruption. Sex and sleaze are everywhere, apart from the Batcave, which may as well be a monks cell.
reviews.author: John McDonald

reviews.text: Although Matt Reeves does make attempts to inflect the tired subject matter with some virtuosity, the universe's over-familiarity and essential stodginess overrides any novelty, to my mind, at least.
reviews.author: PJ Nabarro

reviews.text: Star Pattinson is electric in the role of Batman, expressing so much with his intense silence and reactions to the chaos.
reviews.author: Felix Vasquez Jr.

reviews.text: There's a tactile stickiness to the world that clings to you and immerses you.
reviews.author: Rachel Ho

reviews.text: It's quite possible "The Batman" might be too dark and disturbing for some viewers, but I thought it was pretty terrific.
reviews.author: Jim Judy

reviews.text: This new The Batman is a seductive, and gripping detective tale by way of super-heroism. If this is what blockbuster filmmaking in 2022 looks like, then were off to a great start.
reviews.author: Andrew Kendall

reviews.text: The film I imagine Ricky Fitts would grow up to make after the events of 'American Beauty.'
reviews.author: Keith Uhlich

reviews.text: Matt Reeves’ meandering faux-profound take on Batman spends its over-long runtime telling women to shut up and do as they’re told or face the consequences.
reviews.author: Nick Soulsby

reviews.text: 175 minutes, dark in form and brilliant in execution, that break any labels a preconceived ideas, making the concepto of "superhero movies" lose all its meaning despite the masks and capes showing on screen.
reviews.author: Víctor López G.

reviews.text: ...an above-average comic-book adaptation...
reviews.author: David Nusair

reviews.text: It verges on camp without committing to it, and it essays the operatic without being able to provide the emotional impetus required.
reviews.author: Andrea Chase

reviews.text: Stylish and stark, packed with well-executed action and high-quality performances, The Batman is a welcome addition to the canon of the Caped Crusader. Heres hoping we get to see more of what Reeves, Pattinson and the rest have in mind.
reviews.author: Allen Adams

reviews.text: What this film does achieve, however, is telling a solid new Batman story, one with some pretty compelling twists and a strong point-of-view on who, exactly, the Caped Crusader is. By default, that makes it one of the better Batman movies ever made.
reviews.author: Liz Shannon Miller

reviews.text: As for special effects, they are very good, and Greig Fraser’s cinematography is epic.
reviews.author: Marie Asner

reviews.text: How you like this iteration of Batman may depend upon how you like your serial murderers served and if you like your casting on a binary of Black and White.
reviews.author: Jana Monji

reviews.text: The cast is fine, with Pattinson adding his own touch to a role now undertaken by six different actors in the past 30 years, seven if you go back to Adam West and the original television show of the 1960s.
reviews.author: Michael A. Smith

reviews.text: A beefy, stylised approach and committed performances make this take on the Dark Knight worth a look, even if the film fails to break out of the usual cliched lack of light and colour.
reviews.author: Rich Cline

reviews.text: This is everything I could have asked for in a Batman film. I loved the tone, easter eggs, and so much research that went into this. Bobby Patts brought something different to this character that really stood out. I really loved this film.
reviews.author: Justin Brown

reviews.text: This is at least in the top three Batman films of all time for me. It was a combination of all of the best elements of the Batman character and Gotham as a city. It blew me away. This was fantastic.
reviews.author: Brandon Collins

reviews.text: The Dark Knight returns with a more hopeful take on vengeance
reviews.author: Pedro Luis Graterol

reviews.text: This Batman is as dark, depressed and angry as many of those living in these dark, stressful times. Batman wants revenge, while the villain wants to expose government corruption. Thus, the normal superhero story formula is upended.
reviews.author: Robert Roten

reviews.text: The good guy/bad guy duality — opposite sides of the same coin — has been done to death in past Batman movies. In this one, suffice it to say, it’s taken to startling heights.
reviews.author: Randall King

reviews.text: "... a veritable breath of fresh air in an industry glutted with visually banal superhero films with plots that feel written by committee."
reviews.author: Nathanael Hood

reviews.text: In a film that’s more about the showing than the telling, Pattinson’s moody edginess fits right in.
reviews.author: Nandini Ramnath

reviews.text: The Batman is not only proof that a comic book movie can be sexy, but an indication that the long-gone genre that defined Hollywood in the 80s and the 90s is making a slow but sure comeback.
reviews.author: Carrie Wittmer

reviews.text: The twists and turns, the grim Fincher feel, the growling bruised Batman and the sadistic Riddler, this big-screen blockbuster is heavy-duty and for Bat-fans with a big appetite.
reviews.author: Kate Rodger

reviews.text: I love the way they made Gotham City look.

reviews.text: The Batman sets the bar for the crowded superhero subgenre in a bold, refreshingly auteur-driven manner.
reviews.author: Matt Conway

reviews.text: Reeves self-possessed direction digs into the character with gravitas and precision, making for a reinvigorating return to basics.
reviews.author: Filipe Freitas

reviews.text: Yes, self-parodic travesties like 'The Batman' could be more original. But even a creative Batman story is still just another Batman story. Isn't it time to give the man a rest?

reviews.text: So committed is this film to a reenvisioned Batman look, feel, and face that I never thought of the other films as I watched. It might be the best reboot Ive seen.
reviews.author: Brett McCracken

reviews.author: Alejandro Turdó

reviews.text: Pattinson is more a presence than a character, and he fits in with the dark visuals and chilling elements of the story.
reviews.author: Jackie K. Cooper

reviews.text: If you strip down the characters iconography deep enough, you are left not with a film about capital-B Batman but rather just a sullen sociopath who dresses up like a bat to fight bad guys.
reviews.author: Neil Morris

reviews.text: You can call it brooding -- I call it irritating.
reviews.author: Andy Klein

reviews.text: This movie doesn't earn the three-hour running time... It's an okay Batman movie; it's just too long.
reviews.author: Kevin Carr

reviews.text: Ultimately, this Batman accepts the thankless, death-defying role he’s stepped into, and the sacrifices that go with it. But that choice would be more compelling if it weren’t framed as a tacit acknowledgement of all the inevitable sequels to come...
reviews.author: Adam Nayman

reviews.text: What I like best is that Matt Reeves has delivered something strikingly unique -- not only for a Batman movie but within the superhero genre as a whole. And while I wasn't initially sold on its length, the movie earns its three hour running time.

reviews.text: Controversial opinion: a Batman movie should not be longer than 'The Godfather.'

reviews.text: The Batman isnt just one of the best Batman films, its also one of the best comic book films to date.

reviews.text: The Batman is a triumph where we see the Bat find love, hope, and a sense of understanding that he is not alone in this world.
reviews.author: Lyra Hale

reviews.text: It’s not too surprising that this is Reeves’s film, since the recent Planet of the Apes trilogy is among the most rich, complex, and well-crafted franchises in cinematic history.

reviews.text: An emo-thriller take on the world of Gotham, The Batman explores the mysteries of the dark underbelly of the city with expert world-building and unexpected humor.
reviews.author: Kristen Maldonado

reviews.text: On the whole, The Batman satisfies. It may continually remind you of other films, the aforementioned work by Mann, Fincher and Lumet, but at least this magpie director is pinching from the best.
reviews.author: Jamie Dunn

reviews.text: There's so much to love about Matt Reeves' The Batman: the characters, the cinematography, the stellar soundscape, the incredible world-building. The screenplay could have been a little tighter, though.

reviews.text: The Batman may not knock The Dark Knight from its perch, but it is a fully imaginative reworking of the Detective Comics era, lifted by muscular performances.

reviews.text: I was pleasantly surprised. It's not the Nolan movies, but for heaven's sake better than Affleck...I think Pattinson does a good job with it.
