reviews.text: The Batman may be overstuffed, but the strong cast and impeccable direction make the film an impressive love letter to the DC hero.
reviews.author: Brandon Zachary

reviews.text: Matt Reeves' oh-so-serious Batman presents a fresh, complex and inventively retooled entry in a long and crowded superhero franchise mostly dominated by supervillains far more interesting than its titular hero.
reviews.author: Dann Gire

reviews.text: The Batman ultimately feels like a competent adaptation of the source material refined and emboldened in the image David Finchers Zodiac. Reeves has a knack for memorable shots and incorporates interesting visual perspectives into his Batman
reviews.author: Taylor Baker

reviews.text: Reeves has made the first Batman movie that has the feel of the best Batman comics.
reviews.author: Tim Brennan

reviews.text: (Matt Reeves) transcends the clichés with a masterful, often tense and noir-as-night twist on the mythology that ranks with Christopher Nolan’s The Dark Knight as the best of all the Batman movies.
reviews.author: Cary Darling

reviews.text: The Batman is more Blade Runner than Batman Begins, but this is damn good, consistently surprising filmmaking, and it all works.
reviews.author: Samuel R. Murrian

reviews.text: It’s a hellish fusion of ideas and genres, built on the foundations of some of the best comic book stories but still wholly its own creation, brimming with emotion and angst and tragedy -- and yet, this is not a film to be endured. It’s to be enjoyed.
reviews.author: TK Burton

reviews.text: Despite its flaws, Matt Reeves has marshalled one of the smartest and most mature comic book adaptations in memory. The film is strongest in its first half but the double act between Wright and Pattinson sustains throughout.
reviews.author: Christopher Machell

reviews.text: Superhero reboots have become tellingly frequent, as if being jolted back to life by increasingly desperate electro-shocks. For all the consummate care expended on The Batman’s beautiful surface, its substance subsides through familiarity.
reviews.author: Nick Hasted

reviews.text: In addition to Pattinson, Wright, and Farrell (whose Penguin series cant arrive soon enough), nearly everyone else in the impressive cast likewise brings their A game.
reviews.author: Edwin Arnaudin

reviews.text: Matt Reeves gets caught between not being fun enough while also refusing to lean fully into the darkness offered by his premise, creating something that's undeniably watchable but also very serious and safe.
reviews.author: Ella Kemp

reviews.text: The underlying plot becomes off-puttingly complicated, the tone remains annoying one-note, and one crucial climactic scene goes on so long you think it’s never going to end.
reviews.author: Matthew Bond

reviews.text: Even without the overdone backstory, Pattinson's Batman is a fully realized, deeply-moving character who is immensely interesting to watch.
reviews.author: Candice McMillan

reviews.text: The Batman is inarguably the darkest cinematic vision of the Caped Crusader  and one that prods at the foundations of heroism.
reviews.author: Christopher Cross

reviews.text: The Batman is a terrific individual dissertation in the legacy of the Dark Knight. Brooding, brilliant, and breathtaking, The Batman hits that elusive sweet spot between a made-for-the-masses popcorn flick and a deeply complex political thriller.
reviews.author: Mark Johnson

reviews.text: A smart, thrilling, engaging, and entertaining ride through a Gotham City that I hope to see revisited many more times.
reviews.author: Josh Davis

reviews.text: As expected of a director of Reeves calibre, The Batman is an exceptionally well-made film on a technical level, but in its critical final act, it loses sight of its procedural tone and instead gets distracted by the need to check numerous other boxes.
reviews.author: Rohan Naahar

reviews.text: While it doesn't redefine the Caped Crusader, Reeves and Pattinson provide a solid outing into Gotham. The film could probably be about an hour shorter and have shaved a plot line or two, but it's bound to make some Bat-fans very happy.
reviews.author: Dana Han-Klein

reviews.text: ...deserves credit for shining the spotlight on the underbelly of Gotham, but the storytelling in The Batman is like Bugs Bunny meaning to have taken that left turn at Albuquerque; a meandering foray down a dark rabbit hole that isnt entirely necessary.
reviews.author: Chris Sawin

reviews.text: Stylish and well-cast, but monotonous and with an overlong running time and not enough suspense or thrills.
reviews.author: Avi Offer

reviews.text: No snark, no spandex pantomime spectacle. Just noir mystery, Pattinsons sad recluse a detective in a cesspit of corruption. Relentlessly grim, all darkness and despair, not escapist but of our time.
reviews.author: MaryAnn Johanson

reviews.text: If the film falls short of greatness, because Reeves didnt know when to cut and run, it is, in its final extended form, a superior comic book adaptation and brooding thriller in its own right.
reviews.author: Ed Whitfield

reviews.text: The Batman is the triumph we hoped for, and the film DC have desperately been in need of for a long time.
reviews.author: Tony Black

reviews.text: A gritty and dark noir crime thriller that plays like David Fincher's "Seven." Pattinson, Kravitz, and Wright are the dynamic trio in Matt Reeves's definitive Batman film.
reviews.author: Joe Friar

reviews.text: In The Batman, Pattinson is one of the best portrayals of Batman on screen.
reviews.author: Kate Sánchez

reviews.text: "The Batman" is a crime film, influenced by film noir and police procedurals. It feels unique, and it manages to differentiate itself from the comic book movies that are usually released in theatres every month. Full review in Spanish.
reviews.author: Sebastian Zavala Kahn

reviews.text: Except for a new cauldron of actors, this lengthy and exceptionally grim load of PG-13 (huh?) cinema gives the franchise that keeps trying to reinvent the wheel little to distinguish itself from the previous rest.
reviews.author: John Urbancich

reviews.text: As a standalone police procedural, it works quite well, but as a franchise reboot it’s not enough of a reset.
reviews.author: Simran Hans

reviews.text: You could say every era gets the Batman it deserves. Reeves has made an absorbing entertainment where its rainy streets and perturbed faces speak to our intensely uncertain days.
reviews.author: Alci Rengifo

reviews.text: Previous Batman movies have had noir elements. The Batman feels more like film noir with Batman elements.
reviews.author: Abbie Bernstein

reviews.text: Has very few identifiable "flaws"; it's more that at a certain point, it's hard not to feel ground into submission.
reviews.author: Tim Brayton

reviews.text: Greig Frasers A+ cinematography drenches the screen in heavy horror-noir vibes as fear rules Gotham in this fantastic new Batman chapter.
reviews.author: Matt Donato

reviews.text: In The Batman, Pattinson and Reeves create a superhero spectacle for audiences that goes above and beyond the norm. In lieu of a fatigued origin story, we get an evolution.
reviews.author: Erin Maxwell

reviews.text:
In the end, this may be the best Batman movie.

But it also may be the least entertaining Batman movie.
reviews.author: David Poland

reviews.text: Robert Pattinson and Matt Reeves return the caped crusader to his roots as an obsessive detective with this complex, intriguing reboot.
reviews.author: Norman Wilner

reviews.text: When it comes to elevated powers, The Batman has a rare one: it is not a super hero movie.
reviews.author: Stephen Romei

reviews.text: Director/co-writer Matt Reeves doesn’t present anything especially revolutionary in his approach here, but he incorporates some notable stylistic influences and places an emphasis on detective work.
reviews.author: Dominic Corry

reviews.text: The Batman is a product of this time and place, in other words. A shame that this time and place are so stupid.
reviews.author: Walter Chaw

reviews.text: There's more to The Batman than its style, but I should say something about the film's prop and tech design, which is so good and fun.
reviews.author: Jas Keimig

reviews.text: The Batman lives and dies on its characterizations. They’re pretty good.
reviews.author: Jorge Ignacio Castillo

reviews.text: Gotham City’s favorite vigilante has long been known as “the World’s Greatest Detective.” Matt Reeves is the first director to truly realize that on screen.
reviews.author: Miles Surrey

reviews.text: Lensed by two-time Oscar nominee Greig Fraser, Gotham has never looked so gritty, moody and beautiful... Michael Giacchino's haunting score is fantastic, orchestrating each scene with a balance of intensity and intimacy.
reviews.author: Joanne Soh

reviews.text: Listen, The Batman is a solid outing for DC. But, by focusing on the early, comic-book detective iteration of Batman, it sacrifices some of the potential fun of the character.
reviews.author: Graeme Tuckett

reviews.text: I really, really enjoyed this movie and... I definitely wanted to see it
reviews.author: Andre Meadows

reviews.text: At its best, The Batman drips with shuddering dread. Too bad the movie concludes with a half-hearted attempt at a hopeful resolve, a letdown after so much dark commitment.
reviews.author: Robert Denerstein

reviews.text: Matt Reeves delivers a near-perfect film that’s only occasionally limited by its excesses.
reviews.author: Aniruddho Chakraborty

reviews.text: An emotional, noir, David Fincher-esque take on the iconic character.
reviews.author: Anupama Chopra

reviews.text: This film is on the level of Nolan’s masterful trilogy and transcends the comic book genre in a rather impressive fashion.
reviews.author: Micheal Compton

reviews.text: For fans of the grittier DC movie entries, The Batman may be too sardonic. For those of us who missed freaky Batman, however, it’s an interesting turn, even if it’s not exactly a delight.
reviews.author: Abby Olcese

reviews.text: Coming exactly 100 years after F. W. Murnau’s still-disturbing Nosferatu, The Batman doesn’t earn being called artistic decadence. Its depiction of social horror isn’t fully imagined; it never gets to the core of spiritual repulsion that Murnau touched
reviews.author: Armond White

reviews.text: Owing to the first-rate cinematography, and for Pattinson's brooding and emotionally bruised superhero, The Batman isn't the drudge it otherwise might have been.
reviews.author: Saibal Chatterjee

reviews.text: What Reeves has done here should be taken as a remarkable accomplishment. In an era of studio properties, especially superhero movies, aiming for the safest possible outcome, The Batman is a legitimately out-there film.
reviews.author: Owen Gabbey

reviews.text: The film gets off to a slow and slightly tedious start, taking far too long to get going... However, once the investigation into these murders deepens, the pace picks up and the film gets really fun.
reviews.author: Amanda Keats

reviews.text: It’s not the grand synthesis Reeves may have hoped for, nor can all the villains put together live up to Heath Ledger’s Joker. But if you’re after a full meal of a movie, you shouldn’t leave feeling hungry.
reviews.author: Jake Wilson

reviews.text: Weve seen him campy, broody, neon-splashed, comic book-styled, grittily realistic and whatever it was Zack Snyder was attempting, but this is a whole other Batman, altogether.
reviews.author: Damond Fudge

reviews.text: The result is unexpectedly welcome, a comic book movie that feels buoyed by a mixture of humility and fidelity to its cartoon origins, and which stumbles only when it grasps at being more.
reviews.author: George Elkind

reviews.text: Somehow, through dark magic and incredible craftsmanship, The Batman has managed to bring some truly fresh and invigorating elements to the franchise that are sorely needed.
reviews.author: Drew Dietsch

reviews.text: Reeves delivers clearer action sequences than any previous Batman director. Even better is the way the Riddler is revealed as a mirror image of the superhero who busts Bruce on his privilege.
reviews.author: Kristian M. Lin

reviews.text: The Batman has some stylish trappings and some interesting ideas. But under the mask, weve seen it all before.
reviews.author: Noah Berlatsky

reviews.text: Absolutely everything that writer/director Matt Reeves and cowriter Peter Craig put in the script works. But to be clear, thats works in the sense of how I kept my Mitsubishi Galant working until it caught fire in a parking lot.
reviews.author: Ryan Syrek

reviews.text: The Batman is exactly the gritty crime thriller it was selling in the trailer, but it is not the deep, dark detective story come to smash your notions of what a superhero movie can be.
reviews.author: Jonathan DeHaan

reviews.text: Created alongside Dune cinematographer Greig Fraser, this may be the best-looking Gotham City flick of all time.
reviews.author: Brady Langmann

reviews.text: However bleak and disturbing the movie might be, The Batman's grittiness is in service of an unexpectedly optimistic message, and Reeves brings some much-needed glimmers of hope to this otherwise gloomy picture.
reviews.author: Brendan Morrow

reviews.text: My quibbles with the runtime aside, I think audiences going in expecting a more grownup mystery drama than a tentpole action movie will love The Batman.
reviews.author: Brad Keefe

reviews.text: A bold vision of the character that reboots the franchise in an exciting new way.
reviews.author: Chris Bumbray

reviews.text: Knowing what kind of Batman this is (and, crucially, isn’t) is key to getting the most from this long, dark story.
reviews.author: Chris Knight

reviews.text: It's not my favorite take on Batman or Bruce Wayne, but done well enough that I have more positives than negatives. A good to great film.
reviews.author: Brandon Avery

reviews.text: The Batman proves to be monotonous murk.
reviews.author: Dennis Harvey

reviews.text: Rarely do I use the word "perfect", but I wouldn't change a thing about "The Batman". It's an absolute "must-see more than once".
reviews.author: Susan Kamyab

reviews.text: Wants to be critical of Batman as a vigilante who uses excessive force and use the Riddler to comment on white male radicalization, which may actually feel newly relevant after the freedom convoy, but the points don't land as hard as Batman's fists.
reviews.author: Radheyan Simonpillai

reviews.text: The standout performer among the cast is Kravitz, whose Catwoman is constantly keeping all the men in The Batman on their toes.
reviews.author: Joshua Axelrod

reviews.text: Beneath the rubber ears, he’s all granite-chinned and haunted eyes. Off duty, he’s a tragic, wan, raccoon-eyed Bruce Wayne. He hurts. He suffers. And that’s OK, because his Batman is the tense center of a whirl of well-cast characters.
reviews.author: Thelma Adams

reviews.text: Reeves delightfully returns this property to the realm of adult sensibilities as far as mood, tone and characterization are concerned.
reviews.author: Nicholas Bell

reviews.text: The Batman is a smart and uncompromising work that makes the familiar seems fresh and which does have more on its mind than simply extending a valuable [intellectual property].
reviews.author: Peter Sobczynski

reviews.text: Although it does disappointingly go over the top on occasion, there’s just too much depth and style to The Batman for it to be anything other than a success.
reviews.author: Peter Rainer

reviews.text: ... Just because it's grim doesn't mean it's a drag: this is exhilarating filmmaking on every level.
reviews.author: Kimber Myers

reviews.text: It occurred to me that The Batman feels, in atmosphere and pretensions, exactly like what was so sublimely spoofed by 2017's The Lego Batman Movie. It isn't every day that the target of a parody shows up five years after the parody itself.
reviews.author: M.V. Moorhead

reviews.text: The shame of it is Reeves' hewing to all those established norms negates the elements of the film that do feel more revelatory, creating a kind of mish-mash of ideas rather than an engaging whole.
reviews.author: Piers Marchant

reviews.text: Pattinson deserves another two movies to grow into the character. He looks great in the suit, and he's got the broodiness of Batman down pat. He just needs more time to be the man under the mask and remind audiences he's human.
reviews.author: Courtney Lanning

reviews.text: In an era of superhero gluttony, in which these familiar stories, characters, and visuals tend to bleed together, The Batman holds the rare distinction of creating and embracing its own identity.
reviews.author: Jake Kring-Schreifels

reviews.text: Reeves strikes closer to the core of Batmans ethos than any other live-action depiction, a noir mystery ripe for Gothams murky confines.
reviews.author: Ian Thomas Malone

reviews.text: The Batman just gets darker and more oppressive. This is the pandemic caped crusader, and he has a personality disorder.
reviews.author: James Verniere

reviews.text: My reaction may be mixed but there's lots to love about Mat Reeves' The Batman. It owes more to the likes of Zodiac or Road To Perdition than to common heroes-in-tights fodder ... here's my video take!
reviews.author: Jason Gorber

reviews.text: ... so bleak and cynical that it too often forgets to be fun, which would be forgivable if the central mystery was more compelling or if the films thematic complexity matched its technical ambitions.
reviews.author: Todd Jorgenson

reviews.text: THE BATMAN is not a superhero movie. Reeves eerie tone and subject matter plays more like a horror movie. Matt Reeves has crafted a different cinematic interpretation in THE BATMAN that merits a place in the DCEU with Robert Pattinson as the vigilante.
reviews.author: Lupe Rodriguez Haas

reviews.text: The capable cast all inhabit their roles with panache, but some of the film's potency is lost with certain unconvincing narrative twists and a few characters who feel stale.
reviews.author: Katherine McLaughlin

reviews.text: Only more time under the cowl will confirm it, but based on this performance alone, Robert Pattinson may be the best live-action version of The Dark Knight yet.
reviews.author: Jennifer Heaton

reviews.text: The question is not whether or not The Batman is smart and well put together; undeniably, it is. The question is whether or not you want this particular film about this particular character.
reviews.author: Sean Collier

reviews.text: While its action is appropriately theatrical and its mystery appropriately intriguing, in the end this is a film that lives and thrives on its thematic resonance. It lives in the brain instead of passing through it.
reviews.author: Johnny Gayzmonic

reviews.text: The Batman takes the best of what we have read, watched, and listened to for the better part of a century, and crafted one of the greatest depictions of the character on the big screen to date.
reviews.author: Kevin Brackett

reviews.text: If this film effectively repurposes our shared trauma into something more palpable and satisfying, then maybe Matt Reeves finds something that eludes most Batman films of the past. He makes him relevant.
reviews.author: Alan Zilberman

reviews.text: While The Batman might tread familiar ground... there’s enough that’s distinctive here to ensure it makes good on its promise.
reviews.author: Gayle Sequeira

reviews.text: Pattinson makes a great Batman, but he makes an even better Bruce Wayne.
reviews.author: Rob Thomas

reviews.text: Matt Reeves has a strong artistic vision that's worth seeing for fans of the Dark Knight. The movie is not a home run, though.
reviews.author: Mike McGranaghan

reviews.text: This is a redemptive view of a superhero as sociopath, trying to balance moral courage against a society that believes youre a chump if you do so. Riddle me this  what society does that sound like? Theater tip ... an empty bladder  full experience.
reviews.author: Patrick McDonald

reviews.text: Batman Begins, again.
reviews.author: Sonny Bunch

reviews.text: Pattinson's one-note performance isn't the fundamental problem. The problem is that it attempts to embody the current ethos of deconstructing systems we once believed represented the common good  and that includes the system that created Batman.
reviews.author: Megan Basham

reviews.text: A rock-solid building block that re-establishes the hero for its next decade or so of direction.
reviews.author: Phil Villarreal

reviews.text: 'The Batman' runs too long and could use a Pow, Bam, Whamm, Thwapp, Biff, and Zok, but this is a worthy superhero-detective story.
reviews.author: Jeff Mitchell

reviews.text: Pattinson shares several (although too few) scenes with Kravitz, and their flirty chemistry enlivens every one of them.
reviews.author: Kurt Loder

reviews.text: W hat’s wacky, woke and cast like an indie movie? Answer: this Batman reboot.
reviews.author: Charlotte O'Sullivan

reviews.text: This is only the beginning of a run of new Batman tales. The best thing is, it makes us want to see what happens next in this dark and angry place.
reviews.author: Peter Howell

reviews.text: I didn’t want a retread of the past or another origin story. Instead, I got something different.
reviews.author: Alan Ng

reviews.text: Reeves’ bold and enthralling The Batman marks a radical shift in direction, even from Christopher Nolan’s (comparatively) more grounded trilogy.
reviews.author: Richard Whittaker

reviews.text: The Batman is a standalone film that packs in all the ingredients for a delectably dark mindbender featuring the caped crusader, who is more human than ever.
reviews.author: Ronak Kotecha

reviews.text: The film has some exceptional qualities. Its biggest issues are a bloated, unrefined script and a misguided final act.
reviews.author: Jeffrey Harris

reviews.text: While the film's runtime leads to some bloat, Reeves' noir-influence The Batman stands out as the darkest and most visually inventive film starring the caped crusader.
reviews.author: Alan French

reviews.text: At three hours, THE BATMAN flew by. Warner Bros. will have a huge hit at the box office.
reviews.author: Jeanne Kaplan

reviews.text: I went into our screening expecting a bloated, too-heavy-on-the-action, overly violent, 175-minute ho-hum affair. THE BATMAN is none of these.
reviews.author: David Kaplan

reviews.text: The Batman both feels like a terrific achievement given the comic book saturated climate we live in, and a disappointment for it struggles to retain its identity and flex more than a few muscles.
reviews.author: Akhil Arora

reviews.text: When the villain here says 'we're not so different', it actually carries weight. Pattinson's Batman is a despondent, disturbed, destructive presence.
reviews.author: Adam Kempenaar

reviews.text: The Batman is as good as a Batman movie has ever been, or possibly ever can be.
reviews.author: Tom Santilli

reviews.text: [The Batman] is very long, relentlessly intense, murmured more often than spoken, and photographed, by Greig Fraser, with a glowering gorgeousness that must be seen to be felt. It’s also enthralling and tailored to our time.
reviews.author: Joe Morgenstern

reviews.text: The Dark Knight continues to get darker and darker.
reviews.author: Russ Simmons

reviews.text: Even with multiple sequels and spin-offs planned, there likely wont be another superhero movie that looks and feels like this for quite some time.
reviews.author: Nicolás Delgadillo

reviews.text: Visually, Reeves’ film is spectacular, full of graphic tableaux and painterly touches. It never rains but it pours in his Gotham, a city mired in grey, abandoned by the sun.
reviews.author: Paul Whitington

reviews.text: Matt Reeves innovative makeover reimagines The Batman as a modern-day noir murder mystery, abandoning the action genre.
reviews.author: Dustin Chase

reviews.text: Lacking in light and shade, and definitely overlong, The Batman is nonetheless a compelling and well-performed detective story that, yeah, happens to star a man in a batsuit.
reviews.author: Simon Miraudo

reviews.text: What carries the film are the sly intricacies of The Riddler’s misdeed... and the stunning set designs that range from the crowded, rain-slicked streets of Gotham to the gaping Batcave and an Edward Hopper-styled diner lit in green neon.
reviews.author: Tom Meek

reviews.text: A compelling hard-boiled mystery with a detective who just happens to wear a cape and cowl.
reviews.author: Josh Bell

reviews.text: That willingness to play with the pop art of it all, even as it’s very much doing a modern, grim-and-gritty blockbuster thing, is the truest joy of The Batman.
reviews.author: Eric Webb

reviews.text: Not that The Batman doesn't have its moments. It's just that it only has about 90 of them. I actually liked Robert Pattinson's smoldering broody routine (the first 20 times I saw it).
reviews.author: Lisa Johnson Mandell

reviews.text: The 'most anticipated film of the year' proves to have been worth the wait. Peeling a big black onion for almost three hours -- that's what you're getting with The Batman.
reviews.author: Harry Guerin

reviews.text: The grittiest, gloomiest, and most pitch-black of the entire Caped Crusader canon, The Batman expands the compelling mythology with a neo-noir approach and very gothic Gotham look.
reviews.author: Lynn Venhaus

reviews.text: There's an awful lot going on in "The Batman," maybe three movies worth. But Reeves is a capable storyteller, and the actors are good enough to keep the momentum going.
reviews.author: Michael J. Casey

reviews.text: Even as it may neglect or deviate from aspects of canon in minor ways, it pulls off a few essential new tricks. Perhaps the most essential? It's actually a movie about Batman.
reviews.author: Luke Y. Thompson

reviews.text: There is shuddering set-piece after set-piece with nothing innovative of note. Usually you do, at least, get (lame) jokes between the action sequences but this is so humourless and deadly serious you don’t even get that.
reviews.author: Deborah Ross

reviews.text: Matt Reeves made good on his promise to deliver a fierce and suspenseful Batman detective noir. The film is deliberately somber but not an entirely joyless affair, filled with stunning shots and thrilling action.
reviews.author: Ruth Maramis

reviews.text: One of the strongest elements of the film is how much new ground and fresh ideas permeate The Batman with little or no retread of the character history
reviews.author: Kyle Wilson

reviews.text: The Batman is an amazing world of Gotham. I want to see more from this world of Gotham.
reviews.author: Jeremy Jahns

reviews.text: Dropsical with self-importance, and setting a bold new standard in joylessness...
reviews.author: Anthony Lane

reviews.text: Reeves nails Batman's raison d'etre. The personal grievance, married to intimate violence, is satisfying.
reviews.author: John Lui

reviews.text: When Christopher Nolan was directing the Dark Knight trilogy, he tore into the Batman mythos with fervor, whereas Reeves just seems to be lackadaisically marinating in misery.
reviews.author: Bennett Campbell Ferguson

reviews.text: The Batman -- the man, the film -- is so hard-boiled it's nigh on turned to stone. Alas, the writing is nowhere near strong enough to support this weight.
reviews.author: Keva York

reviews.text: This caped crusader is young, tortured, and frightening in a way that the character has never been.
reviews.author: Jonathan W. Hickman

reviews.text: This very special episode of 'CSI: Gotham' tries to mimic all the moves from David Fincher's 'Seven,' but has a lot more in common with junky '90s knockoffs like 'The Bone Collector' and 'Kiss The Girls.'
reviews.author: Sean Burns

reviews.text: Relentless, dark, diabolic, and dynamic is Director Michael Reeves iteration with Robert Pattinson as a subdued Caped Crusader uncovering sordid clues from each characters past, and it works.
reviews.author: Linda and Al Lerner

reviews.text: A grim, gloomy, lugubrious, violent tale of vigilantism in a dystopian city mired in corruption and cynicism...There are plenty of praiseworthy elements in 'The Batman,' but as a whole it comes across as extremely depressing and self-indulgently labored.
reviews.author: Frank Swietek

reviews.text: It’s the kind of superhero movie that, along with something like Spider-Verse, should be the standard-bearer for the genre going forward.
reviews.author: Nick Johnston

reviews.text: Matt Reeves finally gives us the first Batman movie ABOUT Batman, with no villain stealing his spotlight. A captivating film noir in which Gotham is filtered through the mood and aesthetic of Se7en.
reviews.author: Mario Alegre

reviews.text: We've become so used to superhero movies with a few good sequences sandwiched between lackluster stuff that I wonder if moviegoers are ready for a beautifully constructed one with a beginning, middle and end. That would be "The Batman."
reviews.author: Chris Hewitt

reviews.text: With a sweeping soundtrack, actual detective work, and a surprising turn by a capable Pattinson leading a great cast, this Caped Crusader is learning to be better than he was yesterday in a city losing hope... a reconstruction of the superhero genre?
reviews.author: Kevin A. Ranson

reviews.text: Robert Pattison, following up performances in The Lighthouse (2019), Tenet (2020), and The Devil All the Time (2021), continues to expertly plumb the depths of men with nothing left but anger, vengeance, and violence
reviews.author: MontiLee Stormer

reviews.text: The problem is that the movie, which hampers its value with a bloated running time of 176-minutes, never feels fresh, original, or essential.
reviews.author: Michael Calleri

reviews.text: 176 minutes is a long time to go without laughs. And once you've settled into Matt Reeves universe of Gotham, you kind of brace yourself for whatever might be around the corner, its definitely not a joke.
reviews.author: Tatsam Mukherjee

reviews.text: Batman is officially a buzz kill ...
reviews.author: Dana Barbuto

reviews.text: If previous Batman movies were a tad too upbeat, festive, short, and well-lit for you...
reviews.author: Brent McKnight

reviews.text: Is this Batman THE Batman? Hard to know this early, but Im sure Reeves and Pattinson will be back for more. Theyve accomplished something special here, a Bat with a real brain.
reviews.author: Jeff York

reviews.text: The Batman is a boiled down detective noir that scales back the theatrics of previous versions to concentrate on Bruce Waynes personal issues and gritty action scenes.
reviews.author: Richard Crouse

reviews.text: Reeves cleverly subverts the obvious inklings of an origin story in exchange for a brooding and bleak bat-noir that reinvigorates the cape crusader.
reviews.author: Shikhar Verma

reviews.text: The Batman movie youve been waiting for.. Pattinson is great
reviews.author: Caffeinated Clint

reviews.text: There is something triumphant about Reeves The Batman, and I do like where the film leaves the character before the screen fades to black. But so many aspects dont come together, each refusing to resonate no matter how much I wished otherwise.
reviews.author: Sara Michelle Fetters

reviews.text: The Batman is the first live action Noir Detective Batman narrative. An excellently paced ride with captivating shots, great action, an intense/terrify tone, where Collin immerses, Paul owns, Robert Slays, & Zoe delivers! An amazing superhero thriller!
reviews.author: Samuel Leggett Jr.

reviews.text: The latest iteration, The Batman, cranks the dial hard towards the darker end of the bat-spectrum and gives us a pretty cool (if unnecessarily overlong) take on the citizens of Gotham City.
reviews.author: Mathew DeKinder

reviews.text: Robert Pattinsons Batman sinks his teeth into terminal misery in a dystopian wodge of a movie from Cloverfield director Matt Reeves.
reviews.author: Andiee Paviour

reviews.text: Though Matt Reeves The Batman is very entertaining ... its yet another in a long line of films about fractured heroes thats targeted at appealing to an older crowd at the expense of greater audience inclusivity.
reviews.author: Rob Dean

reviews.text: A solid story, great performances, and intriguing ideas about where to go from here. If you're demanding The Dark Knight from every Batman movie, you're going to be disappointed a lot.
reviews.author: Dan Murrell

reviews.text: Matt Reeves has managed to create perhaps the perfect Batman movie. Never before has it felt like the Gotham Knight has jumped right from the page to real life as he has here.
reviews.author: John Campea

reviews.text: If nothing else, The Batman helps shift Batman back to being a hero for the people.
reviews.author: Thomas Caldwell

reviews.text: Matt Reeves had a vision. He wanted to push the limits and do something we haven't seen done with Batman. He succeeded.
reviews.author: Korey Coleman

reviews.text: The Batman works on many levels, from the actors to the action to its detective storyline. Well just have to wait and see if this version of Batman sticks around for a while.
reviews.author: Alex Bentley

reviews.text: The filmmakers take a simple but somewhat ambitious approach to their storytelling here. They strip the character of anything unessential, redundant, or gimmicky.
reviews.author: Mark Dujsik

reviews.text: The Batman has more in common with Chinatown than The Avengers. Its a pulpy and violent serial killer story in the vein of Fincher thrillers like Seven and Zodiac.
reviews.author: Victor Stiff

reviews.text: After gobs of Marvel Cinematic Universe cotton candy, it's refreshing to get a superhero movie with this much attitude, vision and thematic command.
reviews.author: Cory Woodroof

reviews.text: Again, so much of this is about shock value rather than anything actually scary, since The Batman is handcuffed by its family-friendly PG rating, the result being something like a Saw movie made for Disney+.
reviews.author: Eli Glasner

reviews.text: This interpretation is po-faced to the extreme, but Reeves’s commitment to the material and Pattinson’s preternatural grumpiness in the role make The Batman sing -- though the ballad is undeniably emo.
reviews.author: David Sims

reviews.text: Its a rather highly-polished and extremely well-directed mainstream affair, but the ideas that Reeves infuses his film with, the substance, so to speak, is familiar and feels almost artificial.
reviews.author: Jordan Ruimy

reviews.text: Giacchinos score is the standout aesthetic element of The Batman...
reviews.author: Josh Larsen

reviews.text: Lacks a particular freshness key to making a zeitgeist-capturing phenomenon like the films from Tim Burton or Christopher Nolan, but the effort to bring in a certain kind of soulfulness amid a creepy mystery leads to some often stunning results.
reviews.author: Aaron Neuwirth

reviews.text: The Batman is a journey through the seedy underbelly of Gotham filled with epic action, unmatched cast chemistry, and maniacal villains. Everything that DC fans have wanted, and more.
reviews.author: Tessa Smith

reviews.text: Pattinson is a perfect fit for the cowl and cape in this gritty, pacy and achingly stylish adventure
reviews.author: Andy Lea

reviews.text: Reeves is one of the more thoughtful blockbuster filmmakers out there, but here he never quite manages to transcend his influences.
reviews.author: Alistair Harkness

reviews.text: Reeves brings a real sense of motivation to his re-telling of the character and his why is clear. Even in its stumbles, The Batman doesn’t feel like a money grab.
reviews.author: Emily Zemler

reviews.text: Yet another lugubrious, laboriously grim slog masquerading as a fun comic book movie.
reviews.author: Ann Hornaday

reviews.text: An ambitious and very dark thriller that takes its hero back to his noirish roots.
reviews.author: Rafer Guzman

reviews.text: The first Batman movie to feel not just dark but diseased, like something unclean teetering on the edge of an apocalypse. This is what makes it interesting and, in a number of places, very good.
reviews.author: Ty Burr

reviews.text: 'The Batman' soars with action and atmosphere.
reviews.author: Linda Cook

reviews.text: The most artistic Batman movie ever made...Pattinson leaves his mark on the Bat-legacy as a "broken" Bruce Wayne...but this is another case of a director's ambition getting in the way of his own work...demanding so much patience without actual payoff.
reviews.author: Jorge Rivera Rubio

reviews.text: The Batman is, quite simply, a ponderous bore.
reviews.author: Emily Wheeler

reviews.text: Semi-novel spin on the done-to-death Dark Knight routine ("What if Bruce Wayne was kind of BAD at being Batman at first?") and welcome attempts to address uglier aspects of the vigilante fantasy get overwhelmed by an overplotted script franchise demands.
reviews.author: Bob Chipman

reviews.text: It takes nearly three hours for The Batman to tell its story and that story, while familiar, is the Batman story I've been waiting for my whole life.
reviews.author: Richard Propes

reviews.text: This is a moody, atmospheric and at times genuinely creepy flick, with some top shelf performances and a couple of surprising and quite subversive moments in the final act.
reviews.author: Anthony O'Connor

reviews.text: Creating enough points of difference to distinguish itself from the successful Christopher Nolan-helmed Batman trilogy, The Batman is dark, interesting and a little frustrating.
reviews.author: Matthew Toomey

reviews.text: Echoes with the doubled resonance of the best myths, at once a thrilling adventure and a cautionary tale.
reviews.author: Sarah Marrs

reviews.text: This Batman, played by Robert Pattinson, is our goth Bruce Wayne, more disaffected youth than playboy billionaire, and that allows Reeves, as a director, to play with all kinds of grimy imagery, and as a writer, to grapple with the real function of Batman
reviews.author: Katie Walsh

reviews.text: At a time when many comic book franchises are seeking to go bigger, with cosmic beings and multiverses, The Batman’s down-to-earth approach offers a welcome reprieve.
reviews.author: James Berardinelli

reviews.text: For those of you who wondered if another reboot could find itself an audience after Christopher Nolan did such a fine job with his trilogy, please wonder no more.
reviews.author: Elias Savada

reviews.text: The Batman is a needless collage of not only better movies, but more egregiously of better Batman movies as director/co-writer Matt Reeves and co-writer Peter Craig create an utterly inferior and infuriating vision of the Dark Knight.
reviews.author: Blake Howard

reviews.text: Matt Reeves excellent new film introduces us to the fourth live-action cinematic incarnation of the Dark Knight.
reviews.author: Mark Meszoros

reviews.text: I can’t say I had a good time, but I did end up somewhere I didn’t expect to be: looking forward to the next chapter.
reviews.author: A.O. Scott

reviews.text: Even the doubters wondering if there’s anything more to say about Batman will find this reboot in a league of its own, even if Christopher Nolan’s trilogy remains hard to beat.
reviews.author: Randy Myers

reviews.text: Robert Pattinson puts an emo spin on the Worlds Greatest Detective in gritty, engrossing thriller "The Batman."
reviews.author: André Hereford

reviews.text: This is a Batman movie that really embraces something the comics have done, which is Batman is the true identity and Bruce Wayne is a facade.
reviews.author: Eric Goldman

reviews.text: Nolan’s legacy still can’t be shaken off. But the tweaks are something.
reviews.author: Danny Leigh

reviews.text: Director Matt Reeves and brooding star Robert Pattinson see the Caped Crusader as more film-noir detective than comic-book hero in their mesmerizing mindbender that aims high even when it misses the mark. Its a grenade of pure cinema ready to blow.
reviews.author: Peter Travers

reviews.text: 'The Batman' fires on all cylinders and commits to its darkest impulses without losing sight of the light at the core of its protagonist.
reviews.author: Leigh Monson

reviews.text: We've seen the man become the bat plenty of times. In Matt Reeves The Batman, we see the bat become a man again.
reviews.author: Matt Oakes

reviews.text: The Batman is its own, mostly very effective, strain of gorgeous and thoughtful blockbuster filmmaking.
reviews.author: Matt Lynch

reviews.text: Visually speaking, this is where The Batman excels the most. Matt Reeves has certainly gone all out to make his film looks meticulous with the help of Greig Frasers stunning nighttime cinematography.
reviews.author: Casey Chong

reviews.text: I don’t know if we needed “The Batman,” but Reeves and company certainly elevated it.
reviews.author: Michael Phillips

reviews.text: Once your ears get attuned, and your eyes too, for that matter, since daylight hardly ever encroaches, there is plenty to relish in The Batman.
reviews.author: Brian Viner

reviews.text: While it could be cut by at least 45 minutes, there’s plenty of ‘Kapow!’ to keep audiences entertained in this scary and sadistic trip to Gotham city.
reviews.author: Dulcie Pearce

reviews.text: Underlit and overblown is a formidable combination, though not necessarily in the way Reeves intends.
reviews.author: Mark Feeney

reviews.text: The Batman is a thrilling, cerebral drama that gives us one of the most realistic portrayals of the caped crusader to date.
reviews.author: Emmanuel Noisette

reviews.text: Puts sthe Batman characters into a forgettable, B-minus serial killer thriller, one with a needlessly convoluted plot, too many characters, unconvincing twists, and a terrible villain.
reviews.author: Stephen Silver

reviews.text: The Batman is an OK film that thinks its excellent. It's also so inspired by Fincher's two exceptional pictures about serial killers that I'm surprised it didn't call itself The Ba7man. (Full review in Portuguese.)
reviews.author: Pablo Villaça

reviews.text: It's good but not great, with the emphasis on drama and a pretty complicated plot that is involving, decidedly heavy and, to be frank, not all that exciting. Director Matt Reeves takes his time with the pacing that is big on character, short on action.
reviews.author: Jim Schembri

reviews.text: Reeves' contribution to the latest caped crusader tale is hypnotic with dazzlingly dark visuals and a Se7en/The Crow inspired detective story. It's not as focused as the Nolan trilogy, but boasts a strong start for future Batman detective stories.
reviews.author: Lee McCoy

reviews.text: It all adds up to an epic vision of an age-old tale
reviews.author: Stephen A. Russell

reviews.text: Here, Batmans default state is pure misery, and while that may be something many viewers can empathise with, this is a Batman few would want to be.
reviews.author: Travis Johnson

reviews.text: A magnificently dark vision that resets expectations about the character and his place in the world.
reviews.author: Peter Martin

reviews.text: This is an excellent first chapter in what I hope will be several more to come.
reviews.author: Steven Prokopy

reviews.text: Despite its flaws... Reeves and Pattinson do offer something new and quite exciting with their interpretation of the DC superhero. Die-hard fans will have plenty to chew over, while more casual viewers can admire the exceptional cast and the characters.
reviews.author: Tori Brazier

reviews.text: Even with missteps, The Batman is an impressive movie. It’s not the rousing, over-the-top exciting superhero version of the character we remember from Tim Burton or Christopher Nolan, but it shouldn’t be. This is Matt Reeves' Batman.
reviews.author: Germain Lussier

reviews.text: What it does do, quite effectively, is tell a solid Batman story, with the most soulful and vulnerable Batman to ever grace the big screen. And that much, at least, is new.
reviews.author: Glen Weldon

reviews.text: Not your typical superhero film, The Batman is dark in all aspects. Kudos to Reeves for a different stylization and noir, but the story lacks in originality. Still not kid friendly.
reviews.author: Tania Lamb

reviews.text: Make no mistake, this iteration is here to stay and is only getting started with reminding moviegoers just how phenomenal unadulterated comic book stories can be on the big screen.
reviews.author: Andrew J. Salazar

reviews.text: It didn't have to be nearly three hours, and the disaster-film last act comes right out of the blue. But there's a film noir soul in this one somewhere.
reviews.author: Jim Slotek

reviews.text: In Matt Reeves confident hands, everything is breathtakingly alive and new.
reviews.author: Christy Lemire

reviews.text: The Batman doesn't quite rise above its ubiquitous genre in the way that it maybe hopes to, but when it stays street level it's a tantalizingly creepy mystery, anchored by Robert Pattinson's eerie take on the Caped Crusader.
reviews.author: Esther Zuckerman

reviews.text: Reeves is aiming for a film noir-like Batman story, but the Dark Knight, supposedly the worlds greatest detective, does very little detecting of his own  mostly relying on others to unearth clues and pass them on to him.
reviews.author: Bob Bloom

reviews.text: I left it still humming that Nirvana song and wondering what this messed-up new Bruce Wayne, cape streaming moodily behind him as he rode away on his bat-motorcycle, would get up to next.
reviews.author: Dana Stevens

reviews.text: The Batman emerges from a movie universe, now becoming ubiquitous, where a phony funereal worldview is the only thing that can confer depth.
reviews.author: Stephanie Zacharek

reviews.text: There's a powerful tone and atmosphere created here, one drenched in a pulpy and occasionally terrifying exploration of this iconic character and those that cross him. The Batman is a bold and brilliant examination of a young Dark Knight.
reviews.author: JimmyO

reviews.text: I wish they had taken the time to develop Bruce as a real person with feelings and emotions. Even in a dark and brooding film noir, there still should be moments where the characters breathe and connect.
reviews.author: Rachel Wagner

reviews.text: The Batman is Matt Reeves most ambitious film yet. The jump from a tense detective story to thrilling action to melancholic romance to disaster film is a massive feat, but yes, Reeves has managed to pick up Nolans mantle where others have failed before.
reviews.author: Therese Lacson

reviews.text: Its challenging to sit with this level of moody darkness for so long, but what an unforgettable take on one of the DCEUs most popular characters.
reviews.author: Louisa Moore

reviews.text: "The Batman" certainly mirrors the dismal state of the world today. Any breaks from that dreariness will have to come at a different bat time on a different bat channel.
reviews.author: Adam Graham

reviews.text: The fact the titular character can't solve a series of simple clues is one of the many problems with this flawed but intriguing take on the pop culture icon.
reviews.author: Charles Koplinski

reviews.text: The reality is that there is probably nothing truly novel to be done with Batman at this point... Try as Reeves and his co-screenwriter Peter Craig might, they can’t squeeze much higher-meaning blood out of a fatally depleted stone.
reviews.author: Richard Lawson

reviews.text: Pattinson and Kravitz make for a compelling Bat and Cat while Dano's Riddler terrifies. The Batman is an ambitious, scorching thriller that brings the hero's detective side into the light. Its third act reaches staggering, stunning highs
reviews.author: Robert Kojder

reviews.text: Scaling down beautifully from the silly operatics of the DCEU, Matt Reeves has crafted a movie which stands cape-to-cape with The Dark Knight, perhaps even surpassing it as a forensic study of Gotham’s most famous protector.
reviews.author: Christopher Preston

reviews.text: While very much beholden to Nolan's grounded trilogy, Matt Reeves pulls from several comic and cinematic influences to give THE BATMAN a flavor all its own.
reviews.author: Zaki Hasan

reviews.text: The Batman is such a grandiose cinematic achievement, crafted with a filmmakers skill and Reeves daring to do it his own way.
reviews.author: Travis Hopson

reviews.text: The riddles of The Riddler, with their dime-store greeting-card histrionics, are about as frightening as a frown drawn on a detached baby-doll-head. Truly cornball stuff
reviews.author: Jason Adams

reviews.text: Richly layered in dark intrigue, The Batman takes viewers deeper into Batman/Bruce Wayne's mind than previous Batman films have ever ventured. This top-notch superhero film makes pointed social commentaries along with plenty of stunning action sequences.
reviews.author: Carla Hay

reviews.text: More of a detective mystery than previous Bat-flicks, borrowing in particular from David Fincher's serial killer chillers Seven and Zodiac... Most of all, though, The Batman is a horror movie.
reviews.author: Richard Trenholm

reviews.text: Matt Reeves understands he can't rewrite the status quo on the worlds most bankable hero, but he can try to tweak the formula and audiences expectations. For better or worse, that's something his "The Batman" does incredibly well.
reviews.author: Nate Adams

reviews.text: Impossibly entertaining and ultimately very compelling.
reviews.author: Dan Scully

reviews.text: The Batman is a competently-constructed film with its most significant flaw being it's too darned serious. That grim one-note approach for two hours would be tough. At three hours it gets to be a bit much.
reviews.author: Jeffrey Lyles

reviews.text: Reeves’ The Batman is an impressive exploration of the character’s Year Two, a visually stunning, violent and believably gritty detective film to please the purists and introduce casual fans to a different version of the Bat.
reviews.author: Laura Potier

reviews.text: “The Batman” is impressively made. The acting is first rate, and the chemistry between Pattinson and Kravitz is magnetic. It’s meant to be an important statement. It’s just not a lot of, you know, fun.
reviews.author: Bill Goodykoontz

reviews.text: I’m as surprised as anyone to say that, after watching Pattinson in action, I’m calling on the industry to bring on all its many Batmen, Batwomen, Batbats. Keep ‘em coming hot and ready until we choke on a cowl.
reviews.author: Barry Hertz

reviews.text: Within the confines of its PG-13 rating, The Batman is much more unnerving than previous Batman installments ... The trouble is grafting a somber pastiche onto a superhero base coat can sometimes feel more exhausting than rewarding.
reviews.author: Caroline Siede

reviews.text: Matt Reeves throws us back into Gotham with a New and Refreshing take on the Caped Crusader which taps into the Detective aspect of the character that has been long looked over! Robert Pattinson and Paul Dano shine.
reviews.author: Alex Page

reviews.text: Imagine if David Fincher made a Batman movie but it was censored to air on televisions at Walmart.
reviews.author: Kristy Puchko

reviews.text: The mix of great and subpar makes it a challenge for me, but there is more good than bad...barely. Plus points for reminding me of The Crow.
reviews.author: DarkSkyLady

reviews.text: With his labyrinthine plotting and tragically human ensemble of characters, Reeves has crafted a richly realized Gotham City where there may be heroes and villains, but no one is innocent.
reviews.author: David Crow

reviews.text: The Batman is a gritty stylized police procedural that suffers from some pacing issues, but offers a fresh standalone take on the Batman mythos.
reviews.author: Michelle Kisner

reviews.text: This is high art at the intersection of blockbuster entertainment. If ever a superhero movie were to be considered for big awards, 'The Batman' is it. See it soar.
reviews.author: Preston Barta

reviews.text: The Batman ushers the Gotham crime fighter out of the shadows, to bring justice into a broken world, in this epic new installment. This is undoubtedly the best Batman yet.
reviews.author: Leo Brady

reviews.text: The Batman is a must-see edge-of-your-seat addition to the catalog of Batman films.
reviews.author: Ashley Menzel

reviews.text: I'll take 2 hours plus of the best Batman movie ever made with a little extra fat. I'll take that deal anytime.
reviews.author: Kyle Pinion

reviews.text: Batman nearly dissolves into the night, overwhelmed by and acquiescent to his films own noirish ambitions.
reviews.author: Jacob Oller

reviews.text: Matt Reeves' The Batman is an invigorating balm for superhero fatigue.
reviews.author: Jeffrey Zhang

reviews.text: The performances are as complex as the colour palette (ie not very).
reviews.author: Kevin Maher

reviews.text: What works about The Batman is Reeves and cowriter Peter Craig’s ability to weave suspense in with characters we know from the world of Gotham and make them all feel like a cohesive unit.
reviews.author: Rachel Leishman

reviews.text: The darkness of The Batman is somehow both richly textured and flimsy–a painting done up on newsprint.
reviews.author: Jesse Hassenger

reviews.text: The film succeeds as both a narrative and visual product.
reviews.author: Sam Allard

reviews.text: The Batman is a very good Batman film. To think of it as anything more only leads to delusion or disappointment.
reviews.author: Clarisse Loughrey

reviews.text: That rare beast: a neatly self-contained contemporary blockbuster. Still too long though.
reviews.author: Adam Woodward

reviews.text: From start to finish, “The Batman” is mostly just a collection of bad ideas.
reviews.author: Mick LaSalle

reviews.text: Depressing, dark and endless. I don’t know about you, but this particular time in history does not seem like the moment for a movie that will leave you a) miserable and b) wondering why nobody in Gotham City seems to have heard of light bulbs.
reviews.author: Moira MacDonald

reviews.text: The Batman feels like a turning point for the Caped Crusader.
reviews.author: Callum Crumlish

reviews.text: There’s an unshakable feeling here of “What’s the point?” Not to mention the nearly three-hour length. Holy runtime!
reviews.author: Johnny Oleksinski

reviews.text: Though not a totally radical refit of the Nolan/Snyder era, it establishes a Gotham City we would keenly want a return visit to.
reviews.author: John Nugent

reviews.text: The first 2/3rds of the movie are so phenomenal, it doesn't matter that the final act is weak. Matt Reeves delivers the best Batman movie to date, and Robert Pattinson the best Batman. Mind-blowingly good.
reviews.author: Grace Randolph

reviews.text: To create a Batman film able to compete with  or maybe even eclipse  Christopher Nolans Dark Knight trilogy takes some doing. Matt Reeves has done that with The Batman.
reviews.author: James Mottram

reviews.text: Reeves loves these dead-end apocalyptic environments, and delights in tales that toy with the moral calculus of typical hero narratives. He has given us a Batman that he himself can believe in, not to mention a Batman that feels right for our times.
reviews.author: Bilge Ebiri

reviews.text: It falls on Pattinson's leather-cased Batman to be the hero we need, or deserve.
reviews.author: Leah Greenblatt

reviews.text: It’s a movie of alternately promising and frustrating half-measures, in which Reeves’ shrewd storytelling instincts and the usual franchise-filmmaking imperatives repeatedly fight to a draw.
reviews.author: Justin Chang

reviews.text: Matt Reeves has delivered The Batman we have earned. Bleak, yet hopeful, true to its origins while being very much of our times. And wait till you see that car chase!
reviews.author: Joanna Langfield

reviews.text: A gripping, grimy and sensational street-level detective story, the Dark Knight’s triumphant return is exactly the fresh start needed after a decade of diminishing returns.
reviews.author: Jordan Farley

reviews.text: If dark, rain-soaked superhero flick sounds done to death, this latest Batman may not be for you.
reviews.author: Philip De Semlyen

reviews.text: As a reboot, The Batman is a very good re-introduction of the Batman movie franchise, but one that feels like a victim of circumstance.
reviews.author: Kofi Outlaw

reviews.text: Director Matt Reeves delivers a gritty action thriller reminiscent of "Se7en" and "Zodiac" that finally makes "the world's greatest detective" deserving of the title.
reviews.author: Kirsten Acuna

reviews.text: As grim as the Burton, Nolan and Snyder films were, Reeves and his team have fashioned their own distinctive and stylish variety of grimness, and they commit to it for three whole hours. Frankly, it's amazing that they got away with it.
reviews.author: Nicholas Barber

reviews.text: Loved every single aspect of this film; the cinematography, that score!!, performances and the story. Easily one of the BEST Batman iterations.
reviews.author: Rosa Parra

reviews.text: A combination of Pattinsons faultless delivery and an engaging storyline from Reeves and Craig give this new interpretation the edge over Zack Snyders overly stylised representation of the DC hero. I just wish it had been slightly shorter.
reviews.author: Linda Marric

reviews.text: Inevitably, night falls on the latest Batman iteration with the cloudy sense that – of course – nothing has really been at stake. A classy turn from Pattinson, however, as the crime fighter with an injured soul.
reviews.author: Peter Bradshaw

reviews.text: Robert Pattinson is a perfect fit for the cowl, but this bloated effort lacks focus.
reviews.author: Christian Toto

reviews.text: Director Matt Reeves’ ambitious and excellently crafted The Batman more than justifies its existence as a world-building wonder that slathers a realistic grime across its Gotham City.
reviews.author: Brian Truitt

reviews.text: A superhero-infused take on the noir genre, with Robert Pattinson diving deep into the Dark Knights state of mind.
reviews.author: Collier Jennings

reviews.text: A masterful and heady introspection on vigilantism, told with foreboding grit and intensity atypical of the genre.
reviews.author: Meagan Navarro

reviews.text: The film sounds even better, thanks to a remarkable Michael Giacchino score that alternates minimalist strums and imperial marches; it’s somehow in the same league as the operatic themes Danny Elfman once lent the franchise.
reviews.author: A.A. Dowd

reviews.text: This epic (nearly three-hour) new chapter in the evolution of the superhero is a new milestone for Pattinson, ranking among the best Batman movies and truly marking his re-entry into the big-ticket, movie mainstream.
reviews.author: Neil Pond

reviews.text: Gotham's never been grimmer than in R-Batz's moody but mesmerising detective thriller
reviews.author: Alex Flood

reviews.text: At its best, The Batman is a helluva tough-guy yarn -- an entertaining pulp-fiction epic under the guise of sure-thing blockbuster. At its worst, it’s the cinematic equivalent of a mixtape.
reviews.author: David Fear

reviews.text: The Batman is an epic masterpiece.
reviews.author: Danielle Solzman

reviews.text: A Caped Crusader adventure with a purpose thankfully more meaningful than taking funny-book characters seriously for a fast buck.
reviews.author: Todd Gilchrist

reviews.text: A towering achievement... Its exactly what the Batman franchise needed to be... This is the Batman movie weve been waiting for.
reviews.author: Mark Hughes

reviews.text: Dark, grungy & hugely atmospheric, Matt Reeves The Batman is potentially the most true to the DCs greatest detective yet. This is a gripping noir-esque detective tale.
reviews.author: Nicola Austin

reviews.text: The Batman is a dark, chilling, and compelling interpretation of Batman and Gotham's corrupt underbelly.
reviews.author: Kelechi Ehenulo

reviews.text: “The Batman” is darkly dour stuff — potent but erratic.
reviews.author: Jake Coyle

reviews.text: The Batman is frustratingly safe, a movie full of potential for more and settling for less. It preaches to the choir, reinforcing the same ideas trodden over and over again across five movies.
reviews.author: Joshua Rivera

reviews.text: A Gothic opera version of the Batman legend, full of dark portents with Robert Pattinson as less ego-driven version of the character. A bit long and drags around the two-hour mark, but the first half and finale more than make up for it.
reviews.author: Christopher Lloyd

reviews.text: A sprawling and sinuous urban detective thriller, with the intricately unhinged red-wool-on-corkboard plotting of classic film noir.
reviews.author: Robbie Collin

reviews.text: Arguably the moodiest and most intense the character has ever been portrayed in live-action, 'The Batman' is a strong debut for Robert Pattinson in the cowl and more than lives up to the legacy of the character.
reviews.author: Brian Lloyd

reviews.text: The reward for such an extreme run time is full immersion in the mental health war that is the Batman experience, with Reeves nailing the brutality and awakening of this complicated dark knight.
reviews.author: Brian Orndorf

reviews.text: A sprawling, complex neo-noir thriller that shares more in common with the filmography of David Fincher than with most other superhero movies. Matt Reeves delivers an experience thats unpredictable, unexpected  and perhaps even definitive.
reviews.author: Brent Hankins

reviews.text: The Batman is a reinvention of the iconic vigilante with a powerhouse cast at the forefront, providing a masterclass of visual storytelling at the hands of Matt Reeves. I could've watched five hours of this.
reviews.author: Josie Meléndez

reviews.text: The Batman is soggy, gloomy, dank, rank, filthy, and forbidding. And so I really liked it. It’s not quite as searing or unsettling as Joker, but it pushes further in that direction than any big-budget comic-book movie yet.
reviews.author: Kyle Smith

reviews.text: Matt Reeves delivers a spectacularly striking, remarkable vision, ringing as an echo of previous Batman-centered features, reverberating long after the end credits finish their scroll.
reviews.author: Courtney Howard

reviews.text: It’s a soulful nocturne of corruption and chaos, and as much as I longed for a few more glimmers of humor, at no point during the hefty three-hour run time did my attention wander.
reviews.author: David Rooney

reviews.text: Reeves has taken on the challenge of producing a fresh take for this comic book icon as well and comes up with the novel twist of turning it into a detective story.
reviews.author: Pete Hammond

reviews.text: Zo Kravitz entered the scene, and two minutes into her first sequence I was already thinking: Couldnt this have been The Catwoman instead of The Batman?
reviews.author: Patricia Puentes

reviews.text: With exhilarating action scenes, a layered story & poignant, in-depth characterization, The Batman is a worthy addition to the live-action DC slate.
reviews.author: Mae Abdulbaki

reviews.text: The Batman is a gripping, gorgeous, and, at times, genuinely scary psychological crime thriller that gives Bruce Wayne the grounded detective story he deserves.
reviews.author: Alex Stedman

reviews.text: The Batman features terrible pacing, a much too long runtime, a story that seems to think it's being original while it isn't, and a combination of a score and cinematography that leads to an uncomfortable viewing experience.
reviews.author: Kaitlyn Booth

reviews.text: This isnt quite like any previous version of Batman, and thats a good thing; Reeves and Pattinson have fashioned a grim, desperate super-hero thats largely in line with todays hardscrabble times.
reviews.author: Eddie Harrison

reviews.text: Matt Reeves has outdone Christopher Nolan in presenting a realistic take on the source material without appearing ashamed of its comic book origins. It is the most like a "real movie" any comic book adaptation has felt in ages.
reviews.author: Dominic Griffin

reviews.text: The Matt Reeves directed The Batman is almost oppressive. The Batman creates an unsettling world that keeps the audience on edge as Batman navigates an overwhelming Gotham City one clue at a time.
reviews.author: Fred Topel

reviews.text: That it doesn’t come off as a parody of a parody is a testament to both the holistic nature of Reeves’ vision and the eagerness with which Pattinson buys into it.
reviews.author: David Ehrlich

reviews.text: While so many comic book movies feel like variations on the same ideas, and the same formal execution of them, Reeves has made something distinct and fully realized.
reviews.author: Brian Eggert

reviews.text: A movie that wants to be shrouded in mystery, but its principle one is how a film can create such a compelling Batman while seeming so disinterested in the character.
reviews.author: Larry Carroll

reviews.text: Registers among the best of the genre, even if — or more aptly, because — what makes the film so great is its willingness to dismantle and interrogate the very concept of superheroes.
reviews.author: Peter Debruge

reviews.text: A less gripping redo of previous Batman films and television shows, with a lethargic pace that drains the film of tension and suspense.
reviews.author: Scott Mendelson

reviews.text: As new chapters go, it's a strong beginning; if only it had known when to end.
reviews.author: Brian Lowry

reviews.text: Matt Reeves The Batman should tell audiences that other superhero movies are possible, and yet more, they can be exist outside the formulaic tentpoles filling theaters today.
reviews.author: Robert Daniels

reviews.text: The Batman is an utterly mesmerizing detective story with electrifying execution.
reviews.author: Jeff Nelson

reviews.text: It seems we get the Batman movie for our times And so now, in 2022, we get the darkest Batman yet, one that pictures a Gotham City so drenched in corruption, Bruce Wayne (Robert Pattinson) finds himself looking into his own family history.
reviews.author: Laura Clifford

reviews.text: A slow-burn noir detective thriller, 'The Batman' may not be the film you're anticipating, but it just might be precisely what this franchise needs.
reviews.author: Doug Jamieson

reviews.text: Batman works in the shadows, and the intensity of Reeves action sequences work well there over three hours that never feel bloated or unnecessary.
reviews.author: Sean P. Means

reviews.text: This isnt just a new take on a popular comic book character, its a fully realized vision for a world. One like weve never gotten before.
reviews.author: Kyle Anderson

reviews.text: Reeves weaves a complex narrative that forces the audience to pay attention and helps his cause when, by the time Kyle appears, that attention shakes a bit.
reviews.author: George M. Thomas

reviews.text: The Batman is the stellar start of a new era of the cinema character. Something that works for the most diehard DC comics fans and those who love the character in the movies. Its an excellent time for film.
reviews.author: Julian Lytle

reviews.text: 'The Batman' is a captivating take on the franchise and is in a league of its own. The pacing is consistent throughout its nearly 3-hour long running time, and the ending leaves you craving for more.
reviews.author: Jamie Broadnax

reviews.text: This riveting take on Batman is, refreshingly, more of a detective story than an action spectacle -- although it does offer that element, too, as well as complex characters and relevant themes.
reviews.author: Jeffrey M. Anderson

reviews.text: This just might be for diehard fans alone; less faithful viewers will surely wonder what has happened to all of the standard exhilaration and the general sense of fun.
reviews.author: Mike Massie

reviews.text: An epic crime saga which more than justifies its epic length, "The Batman" aspires to a grandeur few of its superhero-cinema contemporaries can match.
reviews.author: Tim Grierson

reviews.text: Paul Danos incredible performance as The Riddler will send a chill down your spine.
reviews.author: Paul McGuire Grimes

reviews.text: This is the Batman that Ive always wanted to see since I was a boy, and a Batman for the ages.
reviews.author: Alan Cerny

reviews.text: The Batman triumphs as a reinvention of one of cinema's most enduring comic book heroes. Matt Reeves has crafted a bleak, brutal new vision of Gotham City and its tormented protector.
reviews.author: Mark Cassidy

reviews.text: "The Batman" plays brilliantly like a murder horror mystery for 2h15, and then like a boring superhero movie for the last 30m. Thankfully the great vastly overwhelms the choppy.
reviews.author: J. Don Birnam

reviews.text: Matt Reeves takes Batman on a dark knight of the soul and rediscovers a hero.
reviews.author: Sherin Nicole

reviews.text: In terms of tone and scope and storyline, Matt Reeves’ reboot of the ever-fruitful franchise is more of a film noir than a fable about fantastic flying creatures, more Zodiac and Seven than Guardians of the Galaxy or Eternals.
reviews.author: Richard Roeper

reviews.text: While The Batman is far from the best or most consistent cinematic outing for the caped crusader, the film is still undeniably strong with one of the more poignant reflections seen regarding the character and his impact.
reviews.author: Carson Timar

reviews.text: The material here isnt exactly Agatha Christie, but its refreshing to see a superhero film in which the characters take time to think the plot through and in which the plot is worth thinking about.
reviews.author: Oscar Goff

reviews.text: "The Batman is a darker knight than ever before. Reeves movie, wholly entertaining and full of surprises, features Twilight star Robert Pattinson as the youngest Bruce Wayne ever.
reviews.author: Roger Friedman

reviews.text: The most well thought-through outing for the caped crusader since Christopher Nolans durable The Dark Knight from 2008.
reviews.author: Donald Clarke

reviews.text: This is an incredibly well-made film. The score is otherworldly, the action scenes are perfectly crafted, and it captures tone better than most DC movies.
reviews.author: EJ Moreno

reviews.text: The harsh, grimy atmosphere that Matt Reeves has created leans further in to the noirish disposition his narrative delights in entertaining, with his dangerous, violently-minded Gotham serving as the perfect hunting ground for Pattinsons Batman
reviews.author: Peter Gray

reviews.text: Reeves has made the best Batman film since The Dark Knight, with a captivating and rich world that reinvigorates characters weve already seen on screen over and over again.
reviews.author: Ross Bonaime

reviews.text: What impresses most about The Batman is its deep well of interiority, the way it uses the innately mythic nature of comic book storytelling to zero in on the wants and needs of its characters.
reviews.author: Clint Worthington

reviews.text: Do we really need yet another Batman reboot? The answer, after watching Matt Reeves' tremendous The Batman, is apparently a resounding yes.
reviews.author: Chris Evangelista

reviews.text: The Batman presents us truly for the first time with a cinematic interpretation of The Worlds Greatest Detective. This version of the character is as much a sleuth as a superhero. Its a new feel for this type of film, giving it an added weight.
reviews.author: Joey Magidson

reviews.text: A spectacular, thrilling, and impressive interpretation of the character with a stirring story to tell.
reviews.author: Eric Eisenberg

synopsis: Batman ventures into Gotham City's underworld when a sadistic killer leaves behind a trail of cryptic clues. As the scale of the perpetrator's plans become clear, he must bring justice to the abuse of power and corruption that plagues the metropolis.
